The store manager called her into his office, doors closed behind them. He spoke in a low voice, "We're cutting hours again next month." She felt her throat tighten as she realized this meant another struggle to make rent. She looked down at her hands, helplessness washing over her like an incoming tide.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

In the quiet of his small apartment, he hears a faint tapping sound against the wall behind his bed. He freezes, listening intently. It stops briefly before starting again, rhythmic and persistent. His heart races as he imagines his neighbors whispering conspiratorially about him on the other side. He grabs a flashlight, tiptoes to the wall, and presses his ear against it. The tapping stops abruptly. He strains his eyes in the dim light, noticing for the first time a small, fresh chip in the paint where he's never seen one before. His breath hitches as he realizes someone has been listening, watching him from the other side.

Maybe I shouldn't go there. No, I need to go there NOW. This isn't good at all. Something bad is happening. I can't think straight. What if they're trying to get inside my head? Triggering Event: He opened his mailbox to find a greeting card with familiar, neat handwriting. The message inside was brief: "We'll miss you this year." It was from his former students, now grown men themselves, inviting him to their annual Thanksgiving gathering. His late wife had always loved those gatherings, her laughter echoing through the house as she prepared for them. Alone now, he felt a sudden, heavy grief clutch at his heart, each word on the card slicing open memories best left undisturbed.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, what if they're all married now? What if they don't want me there anymore? I bet they've forgotten about me by now; it's probably been years since I last saw them. My mind keeps going back to that time when I gave a particularly tough assignment, and one of my students ended up killing himself because he thought he wasn't doing well enough. Maybe they're thinking of me in the same way - maybe they feel sorry for me and are just being polite. Or maybe they’ve completely moved on, and I'm just an old guy who used to teach them stuff they forgot. I can’t even imagine how awkward it would be if someone brought up my name during dinner. They must have all found someone else to share their lives with, someone better than me. I bet they’re laughing right now, talking about how much fun they had without me, while I’m sitting here alone, missing my wife. I wonder if they remember me as the guy who taught them so many things, or just as some old fool who didn’t know what he was doing. What if they think I’m creepy for showing up after all these years? Do they still care about me, or did they move on to someone new? I hope they didn’t forget about me entirely. What if they’re all too busy with their families to invite me? That’s probably exactly what happened – they got caught up in their own lives and forgot about me. I wish I could

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she stared at her phone, heart pounding. The message was innocuous enough - "Hey, can we catch up this weekend? It's been ages." But it wasn't from him. It was from his sister, the one who always knew how to make her feel like an outsider, even before the divorce. She felt the familiar tightness in her chest, her breath coming faster now. The walls of her once cozy apartment seemed to close in, suffocating her. She gripped the edge of her desk, knuckles turning white, as she struggled against the urge to scream.

Every year marks another anniversary, another reminder that I’m still here, while they’re together. Even after all these years, the pain remains raw. Sometimes it feels like it could consume me whole. His presence is like a knife twisting my heart, forcing her to confront the memories she desperately wants to keep buried. Her mind floods with images of what could have been if things had gone differently. She feels like a part of her died when he left, leaving behind a hollow shell of herself. Generated Assessment: Oh my god... I was so upset when she said he was cheating on me by going out with her without even saying goodbye. This is all because he's been distant lately anyway, but now it feels like everything is falling apart.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, his cheeks flushing pink beneath his silver whiskers, stood at the front of the community center. Triggering Event: A male teacher, 37, divorced, felt his stomach churn as he opened the classroom door. The stench of rotting apples filled the room; their cores lay amidst a sea of crumpled papers on his usually pristine desk. A note read, "Sorry, Mr., but we ran out of trash cans." His gut twisted in disgust at the thought of his students' carelessness.
Generated Assessment: My stomach churned at the sight of the stench, which was probably caused by my own ineptitude in maintaining order. I couldn't help but think that I was too old to teach, and that my lack of energy was reflected in the state of the classroom. It's ironic that I'm always lecturing about responsibility when it feels like no one listens—especially my own students. They seem so... lazy, and I know they wouldn't have left those apples behind if they were more diligent. Perhaps if I were younger, I could inspire them better, but now they just look at me with disdain. I suppose this is why I feel so disconnected from them; I've become a relic of the past, unable to relate to anyone under 40. My divorce has made me realize how much I've lost, and it makes me wonder if I'll ever regain what I had before. Maybe if I spent less time trying to be perfect, I'd find some sense of peace again, but until then, I'll continue to struggle with this mess of a class, wondering if I'll ever be able to make a difference.

She felt her cheeks flush with embarrassment as she hurriedly turned away, wishing the ground would swallow her up.

Triggering Event: The scientist noticed his wife's medicine cabinet was nearly empty, the shelves barren of her usual array of pills. He hadn't seen her take any that morning, and she'd been unusually quiet at breakfast. A chill of worry crept up his spine as he realized he hadn't heard the familiar clatter of pills in days.
